Pfizer and BioNTech announced that their COVID-19 vaccine received full approval from the U.S. Food and Drug Administration in August 2021.

In March 2020, the World Health Organization (WHO) declared COVID-19 a global pandemic, urging governments to implement strict measures such as lockdowns, social distancing, and mandatory mask-wearing. In the United States, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) played a key role in issuing guidelines to limit the spread of the virus. Pharmaceutical companies including Moderna, Pfizer, and AstraZeneca rapidly developed vaccines using innovative technologies such as mRNA. By December 2020, Pfizer-BioNTech’s vaccine was granted emergency use authorization by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA). Later, in 2021, several countries, including Germany, Canada, and Japan, launched nationwide vaccination campaigns. Despite this, new variants such as Delta and Omicron led to fresh waves of infections, putting significant strain on healthcare systems worldwide.

text: On September 5, 2022, the city of San Francisco experienced one of the heaviest rainfalls in decades, causing temporary flooding in several neighborhoods. Despite the disruption, the local government coordinated cleanup efforts quickly and public transportation resumed normal operations within 24 hours.
